Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

A researcher will conduct a study to investigate whether a certain eye drop is effective in relieving dry eyes. Two design plans are proposed.

Plan <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="bold">I</mtext></math>
 Plan <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="bold">II</mtext></math>

Obtain <math alttext="160" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>160</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers from the population of people with dry eyes. Randomly assign <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to a group to use the eye drop each day and <math alttext="60" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to a group to use a placebo each day. Observe the number of people who experience relief in each group after one week.
 Randomly select <math alttext="160" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>160</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people from the population of people who have dry eyes to use the eye drop each day. Observe the number of people who experience relief after one week.

(a) If the researcher were to choose Plan <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, describe, in the context of the study, a statistical reason for using stratified random sampling instead of simple random sampling in this design.

(b) The researcher is considering using an alternate design: a matched-pairs design. Explain a benefit that a matched-pairs design would bring to the investigation and identify a characteristic that can be used to group the <math alttext="160" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>160</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people into pairs.

The researcher conducted the study using the design described in Plan <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The results of the study are shown in the following bar graph.

(c) Suppose one person is randomly selected from each group (Eye Drop and Placebo) in the study. A student claims that the likelihood of selecting a person who did not experience relief from dry eyes is less for the Placebo group than for the Eye Drop group, because the total number of people who did not experience relief in the study is less for the Placebo group than for the Eye Drop group. Explain the error in the student’s claim.

The researcher will use the sample data to complete a hypothesis test to investigate the following research question.

Is there a difference between use of the eye drop and use of the placebo in the relief experienced from dry eyes?

Let <math alttext="p sub E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would experience relief using the eye drop, and let <math alttext="p sub P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would experience relief using a placebo. The hypotheses of the test used by the researcher are as follows.

<math alttext="H sub 0: p sub E equals p sub P. H sub a: P sub E is not equal to p sub P." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext></mtext><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext></mtext><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

(d) Describe, in the context of the study, the consequence of making a Type <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> error.

The conditions for inference have been met. A <math alttext="99%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>99</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confidence interval to estimate <math alttext="p sub E minus p sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="negative 0.08 comma 0.32" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.08</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>0.32</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(e) Based on the confidence interval, how should the researcher answer the research question? Explain your answer.
